title: U.S. Rule Forcing Visa Applicants to Provide Social-Media Info Targeted by Lawsuit
summary: Suit claims regulation violates constitutional freedoms of speech, association. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration was accused of imposing a form of unconstitutional surveillance by requiring most U.S. visa applicants to provide information on social-media accounts, according to a lawsuit filed on Thursday-the latest legal test of the president's campaign to more tightly control entry into the country.

title: Doubts Surface Over Giuliani-White House Budget Office Calls
summary: Number associated with OMB is also linked to several other offices in the White House. WASHINGTON-House Democrats earlier this week released records asserting that Rudy Giuliani was in contact with a phone number associated with the White House budget office, where $400 million in aid to Ukraine was temporarily put on hold this summer.

title: Finance Executives Are Less Optimistic About Revenue Growth, Expansion
summary: Although profit and revenue are still expected to rise, the rate of growth is expected to slow, survey shows. Finance executives are closing out the year with lower expectations for profit and revenue growth at their companies. They are also increasingly cautious when it comes to capital spending and expansion planning.

title: BlackRock Executive Ousted for Failing to Disclose Employee Relationship
summary: 'I engaged in a consensual relationship with one of our colleagues without reporting it. I regret my mistake.'. A contender for the top job at BlackRock Inc. was ousted from the money-management giant for failing to disclose a relationship with an employee under his reporting line, the latest high-profile instance of executive misconduct at a major U.S. company.

title: New York Lawmakers Preparing Gig-Worker Bill Eye California Challenges
summary: Golden State's new law reclassifying contract workers has prompted strong pushback. ALBANY-New York state lawmakers said they had concerns about the phrasing of a new California law intended to reclassify contract workers for app-based companies as traditional employees, as they prepare their own gig-economy legislation.

title: OPEC Agrees to Deeper Cuts Ahead of Aramco IPO
summary: Experts doubt decision will lead to real oil-production cuts. VIENNA-OPEC agreed Thursday to deepen curbs on crude output by about 40% next year, cartel officials said, as Saudi Arabia pushes for higher oil prices amid the initial public offering of its state-controlled oil company.

title: Glencore Faces Bribery Probe
summary: The U.K.'s Serious Fraud Office said it was investigating the mining and trading giant on suspicions of bribery. LONDON-Britain's top financial cop said it is investigating Glencore PLC for alleged bribery, sending shares of the mining and commodities-trading company down 9% and adding to regulatory woes elsewhere that have weighed on the company all year.

title: U.S. Telecom Company Discloses Potential U.S. Sanctions Violations
summary: Comtech Telecommunications is being investigated for potential violations of U.S. sanctions on Sudan. Comtech Telecommunications Corp. is being investigated for potential violations of U.S. sanctions on Sudan after the company disclosed the possible noncompliance to the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control, the company said in a regulatory filing.

title: Probe Finds 'Squalor' and Vermin in New York City Homeless Program
summary: A municipal-run program to relocate homeless shelter residents paid landlords a year of rent upfront despite the poor conditions for residents. A New York City-run program to relocate homeless shelter residents outside the city placed some people in apartments without heat and infested with mice and vermin, according to a report released Thursday.

title: Corporate Compliance Efforts Count-But With Limits, Official Says
summary: Having a good program isn't enough if companies aren't detecting and responding to red flags, the official said. OXON HILL, Md.-The Justice Department is giving increasing consideration to companies' efforts to prevent legal infractions before they happen. But even the best legal compliance programs can't outweigh particularly egregious misconduct, one official said.

title: GM, LG to Spend $2.3 Billion on Electric-Car Battery Venture
summary: New factory would be built near Lordstown, Ohio, and employ more than 1,100 workers. General Motors Co. and South Korea's LG Chem plan to build a large battery factory in Ohio, the latest example of an auto maker plowing money into the development of electric cars.

title: Biogen Details Case for Controversial Alzheimer's Drug
summary: The biotech company presented data for its experimental Alzheimer's drug after terminating studies in March. Biogen Inc. on Thursday tried to make the case for why two aborted studies of its experimental Alzheimer's disease drug support its plan to seek approval from U.S. regulators, but skeptics said they remained unconvinced that the drug is effective.

title: Trudeau Signals Tax Cuts, Climate Change as Priorities in Second Term
summary: Canadian prime minister's policy agenda presented as he embarks on leading a minority government. OTTAWA-Cutting taxes for middle-income earners will be the first policy priority for re-elected Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who laid out his plans Thursday as he embarked on his second mandate, this time as the head of a minority government.

title: Best-Selling Books Week Ended November 30
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: More Uninsured People, Faster Growth in Health-Care Spending Due to ACA Tax, Report Says
summary: Data showing shifts in coverage, drug-price trends is set to fuel more political squabbling. More Americans are going without health coverage and the pace of spending on health care nationally is rising in part because of an Affordable Care Act tax on insurers, Trump administration officials said Thursday.

title: Former Cardinal McCarrick Sued for Sex Abuse
summary: Defrocked priest accused in two suits since New Jersey's new law went into effect. Two men have filed lawsuits accusing former Cardinal Theodore McCarrick of sexual abuse since a New Jersey law went into effect that gives people a new opportunity to sue their alleged assailants.

title: United Airlines CEO to Step Down
summary: Scott Kirby will take over in May; he has led an aggressive expansion as the carrier's president. United Airlines Holding Inc. said its chief executive, Oscar Munoz, will step down after four-and-a-half years at the helm, promoting an air-travel veteran to continue one of the industry's biggest turnarounds.

title: 'The Aeronauts': Floating on Empty
summary: Historical fictions and silly science sink Tom Harper's tale of Victorian exploration.. A valiant pilot and her scientist passenger fly a lighter-than-air balloon to stratospheric heights in "The Aeronauts," a heavier-than-air adventure, set in Victorian England, that seldom rises above the level of elegant hokum.

title: 'Portrait of a Lady on Fire' Review: The Art of Seeing
summary: A female portraitist must surreptitiously paint a bride-to-be who is being pressured into an arranged marriage in Céline Sciamma's visually sumptuous film.. This is not the ideal time to write about "Portrait of a Lady on Fire," since it won't go into full national distribution until mid-February. But the film is starting a limited run to qualify for Oscar consideration, you'll be hearing lots about it, and it's just too good to ignore over the course of the next two months. Here, then, is something between a preview and a review, with more to come at the later date.

title: Treasury to Sell $156 Billion of Debt
summary: U.S. Treasury Department's auctions next week will include three- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. The U.S. will auction $156 billion in securities next week. Details (all with minimum denominations of $100):

title: Traders Eye Long-Term Hedges on the S&P 500
summary: Cost of hedges on major index rise, pushing options measure called skew near record. Market volatility recently receded to the lowest level in months, but traders have picked up contracts that would pay out if stocks fall over the next year.

title: Stocks Edge Up as Investors Parse Trade Headlines
summary: President Trump says negotiations are going 'very well' between the U.S. and China. U.S. stocks edged higher Thursday as investors parsed the latest headlines on the trade dispute with China and looked ahead to Friday's jobs report.

title: Voluntary Evacuation Order Lifted for Texas City
summary: Officials cite improved air quality in Port Neches, where there were explosions at a chemical plant last week. Voluntary evacuation orders were lifted for a Texas city where explosions at a chemical plant sent plumes of smoke into the sky, with officials citing improved air quality.

title: Twitter Sells Bonds at Low Rate
summary: Sale is latest sign of the appeal of bonds that are just below investment grade. Twitter Inc. sold its first-ever unsecured bonds on Thursday at a lower interest rate than initially expected, reflecting robust demand from investors drawn to the social-media company's ample cash flow.

title: Tiffany Dragged Down by Weak U.S. Demand
summary: Jeweler is being acquired by LVMH in a more than $16 billion deal; China sales strong. Tiffany & Co. reported flat quarterly sales as softness in the U.S. market offset growth in mainland China, highlighting the challenges LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE faces once it takes over the famed American jeweler.

title: U.S. Targets Russian 'Evil Corp' Hacker Group With Sanctions, Indictments
summary: The group allegedly stole $100 million from banks. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration Thursday placed a $5 million bounty on the leader of a Russian hacker group called Evil Corp for his alleged work for Moscow's intelligence agency, part of what U.S. officials say is a broader reprisal for a Kremlin-directed cyber offensive against the U.S.

title: Trump's Tax Cuts Reduce U.S. Burden to One of Lowest in the World
summary: Report says U.S. tax as a percent of GDP is the lowest among grouping of major economies except Ireland, Chile and Mexico. WASHINGTON-President Trump's 2017 tax cuts reduced the U.S. tax burden to one of the lowest among major world economies, according to a Thursday report by an intergovernmental organization.

title: Mnuchin Working Closely With Fed, Bank Regulators on Repo Market Issues
summary: Treasury is also reviewing timing of corporate tax payments around repo market strain. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Thursday he is working closely with the Federal Reserve to make sure there are ample reserves, or deposits banks keep at the Fed, following funding strains in money markets in September.

title: Biden Calls Iowa Man 'Damn Liar' Over Ukraine Remark
summary: After retiree suggests candidate is too old to be president, Biden says, 'Let's do push-ups together, man'. NEW HAMPTON, Iowa-Joe Biden got into a heated exchange with an Iowa man who asked him about his son's dealings in Ukraine and suggested the 77-year-old former vice president was too old to lead the nation.

title: Google Management Shuffle Points to Retreat From Alphabet Experiment
summary: Founders' step away mirrors broader shift as Silicon Valley faces backlash against big tech. Sundar Pichai's appointment this week as chief executive of Google parent Alphabet Inc. effectively shifts the focus back on the company's advertising profit machine and away from its "moonshots" and other potential new businesses.

title: What to Wear to the Office Christmas Party-That You Won't Regret
summary: A sophistication strategy for women who don't want to look like Mrs. Claus or an outdated caricature of a punch-thirsty vixen. OFFICE HOLIDAY parties are vexing events to dress for. Like funerals in the tropics and weddings at nudist resorts, they don't immediately compute. For one awkward evening, you drink Cava and sing karaoke with the same people you haggle over Excel spreadsheets with in normal life. Unsurprisingly, the work shindig has been mined extensively for comedy: The sitcom "The Office" featured nearly 10 years worth of holiday party episodes; an unmerry moment in "Seinfeld" captured Elaine jiving uncontrollably on the dance floor at her affair; "Mad Men" showcased the boozy yuletide conga line pictured. There is even an entire, regrettable 2016 movie called "Office Christmas Party."

title: Students Argue in Court for Right to Learn Civics
summary: Lawyers for Rhode Island students argue the Constitution guarantees an education that prepares them to be capable citizens. A federal judge in Providence, R.I., heard arguments Thursday in a case that tackles a novel question: Do students have a right under the U.S. Constitution to an education that prepares them to be capable citizens?

title: Sage Therapeutics Shares Plummet on Depression-Treatment Study Results
summary: Results mark first miss on major depression trial for SAGE-217, setting company on track to shed $4.4 billion in market value. Sage Therapeutics Inc.'s share price was cut by more than half Thursday, erasing more than $4 billion in market value after the company said its treatment for depression failed in a late-stage trial.

title: Kroger's Overhaul Crimps Profit Again
summary: Grocer boosted same-store sales as it slowed pace of store renovations. Kroger Co. 's investments in store renovations and technology hurt profit again in its latest quarter, when the grocer tempered its overhaul plans to boost future sales.

title: Pentagon Official Says More Troops Might Be Sent to Mideast
summary: Potential expansion in U.S. military footprint in region could come in response to threats from Iran. A top Pentagon official told senators that U.S. military officials are considering bolstering the U.S. force presence in the Middle East to counter threats from Iran following a significant buildup throughout the year.

title: The Luxe Way to Fly? Book a Hotel With Its Own Plane
summary: Hotel companies like Aman and Four Seasons are nosing into the premium airline business but only for the loftiest fliers. WHAT DO REALLY cushy hospitality brands and air travel have in common? Not much. But now some top hotel groups are trying to help their fans skip the indignities of commercial flights by launching their own planes. Aman Private Jet is a 12-passenger Bombardier Global 5000, based in Singapore, and available for charter. A dedicated concierge can arrange pickup at, say, your spread in the Hamptons and delivery to Utah's Amangiri resort. There are planned trips, too. Six nights in Southeast Asia includes stops at Aman resorts in Laos, Cambodia, Thailand and Vietnam (aman.com). Four Seasons has offered trips around the world by private jet for years (in partnership with TCS World Travel). In 2021, its first custom-built plane-a 48-passenger Airbus A321neoLR-will take flight, starting with a three-week trip from Dubai, visiting Angkor Wat, the Seychelles and Rwanda. Seats are $169,000 each, but at least you won't have to pay extra baggage fees (fourseasons.com).

title: Is Doc. Warren's Prescription the Right One?
summary: Simon Johnson says Sen. Elizabeth Warren's plan would "cut costs by reducing inefficiency." Government has never been known for efficiency.. Regarding Simon Johnson's "Warren Has the Remedy for Health Costs" (op-ed, Dec. 2): Prof. Johnson says Sen. Elizabeth Warren's plan would "cut costs by reducing inefficiency." Government has never been known for efficiency. I'd refer any doubters to the U.S. Postal Service, FEMA or the Pentagon's purchasing process.

title: Congress Must Act Soon to Save the USCIRF
summary: The U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom was created to be independent from the State Department, not from Congress.. Kristina Arriaga's "Congress May Set Back Religious Freedom" (Houses of Worship, Nov. 15) mischaracterizes and undermines the bipartisan effort in Congress to reauthorize the U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom (USCIRF). As someone who has worked in this space nearly a decade, I was disappointed to read it.

title: The NFL Wants to Better Predict Injuries
summary: The league has entered a partnership with Amazon Web Services to learn more about what drives the game's most dangerous plays. Imagine an NFL player who receives a crushing blow to the head. Far away, a computer detects a trend showing that other players have suffered injuries on similar plays. That information could rewrite rulebooks to eliminate the play in question, changing the way football is played.

title: Thwarting the 'Hi Granma' Spam Telephone Scam
summary: Having had four such "Hi, Granma" calls, I found this works like a charm.. Regarding "Family & Tech: Beware the Gift Card Scam" (Life & Arts, Nov. 20): Immediate reassurance that one isn't talking to a loved one in trouble comes just by asking the caller "what's your name?" and any other personal data you know but the scammer doesn't. Having had four such "Hi, Grandma" calls, I found this works like a charm. They hang up.

title: TD's Profit Slumps on Falling Rates, Weaker Credit
summary: Adjusted earnings of C$1.59 a share down from year earlier, missing analysts' expectations. Toronto-Dominion Bank Group said it remains poised to take advantage of acquisition opportunities in the U.S. despite a profit slump prompted by declining interest rates and worsening credit quality.

title: 'The Confession Killer' Review: The Fake Artist
summary: The true-crime trend turns to Henry Lee Lucas, whose confessions to an impossibly large number of killings were deeply flawed yet readily embraced by the police.. The genre of true crime can involve a lot of ugly, nasty, complicated things, but the "unsolving" of murder mysteries isn't usually one of them. Of course, Henry Lee Lucas is not your usual case. Nor is "The Confession Killer" any kind of standard documentary: Once believed to be the most prolific serial killer in the annals of American crime, Lucas is now regarded as one of its greatest frauds-and, as the series attests, one that law enforcement perpetrated upon itself.

title: 'Work in Progress' Review: Laughing Through the Pain
summary: The despairing comedy of Showtime's new series exists mostly within an LGBTQ galaxy, but its universe will be familiar to everyone.. If Larry David, Hannah Gadsby and Samuel Beckett had a ménage à comédie, it might look like "Work in Progress," in which the funniest stuff probably shouldn't be funny at all. The despairing nucleus of the eight-episode series is Abby (Chicago improv veteran Abby McEnany), a self-described 45-year-old "queer dyke" who decides to kill herself during a "big breakthrough" with her therapist-who then dies in the middle of the session. "Was your big breakthrough," her friend Campbell (Celeste Pechous) later asks, "the realization that your problems were so big your therapist preferred death over listening to them for one more minute?" How can we laugh? How can we help it?

title: Higher Emissions Standards Help Extend Booming Palladium Rally
summary: Supply deficits persist, despite predictions car makers will replace the metal with cheaper alternative. Prices for a rare metal used to filter emissions in gasoline car engines continue rising, defying predictions that substitution of a cheaper alternative by auto makers would halt a yearslong rally.

title: 2020 Lexus LS: Meet the 'Finest Car Built in Japan'
summary: It may have a face only a mother could love, but this new luxury hybrid is well-built, powerful, quick and smartly designed throughout, says Dan Neil. IN THE EYES of at least a few readers, Lexus leaned into the ugly with its fifth-generation LS sedan (2018) and the related LC coupe. Both cars were born with especially exuberant versions of the company's "spindle" grille design-though it strikes me as more of a cinched corset, or a sack of gold, or a purse seine, gravid with black fish.

title: 'A Christmas Carol' Review: A Cold-Weather Favorite Loses Its Chills
summary: Matthew Warchus has collaborated with Jack Thorne on a watered-down adaptation of Dickens's seasonal classic that removes any material that could be triggering to sensitive audiences.. New York

title: Fiat Chrysler Is Told to Pay $1.6 Billion in Italian Back Taxes
summary: Italian-American car maker suffers a blow as it tries to complete its merger with Peugeot's owner. MILAN-Italy is demanding €1.4 billion ($1.6 billion) in unpaid taxes from Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV, in another hit to the car maker as it tries to complete its merger with Peugeot maker PSA Group while defending itself against a major lawsuit from General Motors Co. in the U.S.

title: China Says U.S. Trade Talks Remain on Track
summary: Negotiating teams have maintained close communication amid recent rise in tensions, Beijing says. BEIJING-China's trade negotiations with the U.S. remain on track, Beijing said, offering official reassurance after tensions flared between the world's two biggest economies over human-rights issues in China.

title: Brazil Underreports Exports Following Data Glitch
summary: Data-processing service Serpro claims responsibility for not detecting errors. BRASÍLIA-A glitch in Brazil's handling of trade data led the government to underreport exports in recent months by about $7 billion, likely causing the real to weaken and forcing authorities to revise other economic indicators.

title: Aramco Valued at $1.7 Trillion in World's Biggest IPO
summary: Saudi oil giant's IPO breaks record set by Alibaba Group in 2014. Saudi Aramco priced its initial public offering Thursday at the high end of the targeted range to give the oil giant a total value of $1.7 trillion in the world's biggest-ever IPO.

title: Latin Kings Gang Leaders, Members Arrested in Mass Raid
summary: The operation, five years in the making, focused on the gang's East Coast leadership. Leaders of what authorities call one of the largest criminal organizations in the world were arrested and charged with federal racketeering, drug and firearms offenses.

title: EU Takes First Steps to Establish Anti-Money Laundering Supervisor
summary: The bloc's finance ministers called on the European Commission to evaluate whether to move forward with establishing an EU-level agency. The European Union should consider creating an independent agency to supervise anti-money-laundering compliance, the bloc's finance ministers said Thursday.

title: Pelosi Rebuts Idea That She Hates Trump
summary: Speaker pushes back at allegation made by Republicans; 'Don't mess with me when it comes to words like that'. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi had ended her weekly press conference on Thursday when a reporter shouted: "Do you hate the president?" The 79-year-old California Democrat pivoted on her heels, pointed at the reporter and said: "I don't hate anybody."

title: France Grinds to a Halt as Massive Strike Begins
summary: Tens of thousands of protesters, including lawyers, teachers, students and air-traffic controllers, hit the streets across the country. PARIS-Cities across France were paralyzed by a massive public transport strike against a planned overhaul of France's pensions system, in a test of President Emmanuel Macron's resolve to modernize the economy.

title: What Steve Cohen Means for the Future of the Mets
summary: The full effect of new ownership for New York's star-crossed baseball team won't be felt for some time. The identity of the New York Mets doesn't revolve around a star player or innovative front-office executive, like virtually every other organization in baseball, but rather the men responsible for signing the checks. The Mets' defining characteristics-their economic austerity, their propensity for baffling public-relations snafus, their longstanding inferiority complex-all stem from the ownership of Fred Wilpon and his son, Jeff.

title: Huawei Unveils Latest Legal Challenge Against the U.S.
summary: 'FCC should not shut down joint efforts to connect rural communities in the U.S.,' Huawei's chief legal officer says. SHENZHEN, China-Huawei Technologies Co. filed a fresh legal challenge against the U.S., seeking to block a Federal Communications Commission decision last month that further restricts the Chinese telecom giant's ability to operate in the U.S.

title: Gates Foundation CEO to Step Down
summary: Susan Desmond-Hellmann will be succeeded by Gates foundation veteran Mark Suzman in February. Susan Desmond-Hellmann, chief executive of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and a longtime leader in health care, said she plans to step down from her post early next year, for health and family reasons.

title: American Firms Import Fewer Chinese Goods
summary: U.S. trade gap narrowed in October; Imports declined across the board, including sharp drop in consumer goods like cellphones, toys and apparel. WASHINGTON-American firms bought fewer Chinese-made consumer goods in October in the wake of new U.S. import tariffs, and the overall trade deficit narrowed.

title: A Norwegian-Argentine Union that Wasn't Meant to Be
summary: Norwegian Air Shuttle has sold its Argentine subsidiary, which was always an unlikely gamble on a remote market. Commitment and love are often seen as key ingredients of a successful marriage, but geographical proximity and financial health matter, too. That, and not putting money in Argentina.

title: FCC Says 5G Doesn't Pose New Cellphone-Radiation Threats
summary: Agency maintains existing limits on radiation exposure from cellphones, network equipment. The Federal Communications Commission has decided to allow the rollout of new 5G wireless networks without making changes to federal safety limits for cellphone-radiation exposure.

title: Pick Up Kroger on Sale
summary: The grocer's shares remain cheap even as its sales growth is accelerating. Investors still aren't sold on Kroger . It may take several quarters of solid execution to make them comfortable.

title: Safety and Biotech Investing Don't Mix
summary: Sage Therapeutics' clinical-trial blowup should remind biotech investors that even the healthiest-looking stock is at risk.. Investors have a fresh reminder of an old truth: Safety is an elusive quality in biotech stocks.

title: Fed Adds $107.4 Billion in Short-Term Liquidity to Financial Markets
summary: New York Fed's action includes overnight repurchase agreements totaling $78.7 billion. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York added $107.4 billion in temporary liquidity to financial markets Thursday.

title: U.S. Soccer Federation's Struggles Deepen
summary: Men's team produced shaky results in 2019, most youth national team coaches have left and the federation is operating without a CEO. More than two years have passed since the U.S. men's soccer team lost to Trinidad and Tobago, failing to qualify for the 2018 World Cup and sending the U.S. Soccer Federation tumbling into turmoil.

title: Winter Boots You Can Actually Wear With a Dress
summary: With this new troop of sleek yet weather-resistant shoes, the days of swapping out your bulky snow boots for heels at the office may be over. All-weather bona fides: The rubber platform heel elevates this sleek Italian leather pair in the slush, while a substantial toe guard plows through modest snow drifts.

title: Mansion Once Owned by a Vanderbilt Is Listing for $68 Million
summary: The seller, antiques dealer Carlton Hobbs, bought the Neoclassical property for $10.6 million in 2002. An Upper East Side mansion built around 1930 as the home of the socialite Virginia Graham Fair Vanderbilt-wife of William Kissam Vanderbilt II, a member of the prominent New York family-is being shopped off-market for $68 million, according to marketing materials seen by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Long U.S. Jobs Boom Gets Longer
summary: Hiring at small firms surged again in November.. Can anything stop the great American jobs machine? Amid historically tight labor markets, trade concerns and slowing economic growth, U.S. small businesses still managed to accelerate their hiring last month. That's according to the latest employment report from the National Federation of Independent Business, due out later today.

title: GOP Rep. Tom Graves Won't Seek Re-Election
summary: Congressman is latest of more than two dozen House Republicans who won't be on the ballot next year. WASHINGTON-Rep. Tom Graves (R., Ga.) said he won't seek re-election in 2020, bringing to two dozen the number of House Republicans in the current Congress who have either stepped down or announced plans not to run next year.

title: Elon Musk Buys Out the Neighbors
summary: The Tesla and SpaceX chief has spent around $100 million on homes, including a cluster of six in a leafy Los Angeles neighborhood.. Elon Musk, the high-profile billionaire who has placed bold bets on driverless cars and space flights, is known for his over-the-top antics: He appeared in a Los Angeles court earlier this week, telling a jury that a Twitter message he sent suggesting a Thai cave rescuer was a pedophile wasn't meant to connote the word's dictionary definition and was in response to what he viewed as an unprovoked attack.

title: Slack Gets Ahead of the News
summary: Messaging company sees Microsoft gaining further ground in users, but still questions quality. At least give Slack Technologies credit for not ignoring the elephant in the room.

title: An Under-the-Radar Tropical Paradise
summary: The Indonesian island of Lombok isn't as popular-or strategically slick-as neighboring Bali, and it's in no big rush to change. TWENTY YEARS ago, I felt a midlife crisis coming on, so I pulled up stakes in Manhattan and moved to Indonesia, to give life in tropical paradise a try. I've divided my voluntary exile between Bali and its neighbor to the east, Lombok. I started in Bali, which has for centuries attracted dreamers and drifters seeking escape from industrial civilization. The Balinese are both hospitable and canny marketers: They made their land a legend-"Island of the Gods"-and got rich catering to stressed-out foreigners. In my early days in Bali, I would rise at first light and ride my bike to Legian Beach for a swim, as dawn came booming up from the Indian Ocean.

title: In Figure Skating, Is It Ever OK to Perform to "Schindler's List?"
summary: The skating world doesn't see a problem with skaters' depictions of Holocaust movies. Outsiders cringe.. A skater's controversial costume for a program set to the soundtrack of "Schindler's List" is putting an uncomfortable spotlight on the sport's longstanding affinity for performances to the music of movies about the Holocaust.

title: Once a Tool of the Elite, Metal Credit Cards Are Everywhere
summary: Resume Subscription. Pulling out a black metal American Express card shows power and the wherewithal to make a six-figure purchase. James Bond wields one.

title: I'm Jewish. Please Wish Me a Merry Christmas.
summary: Season's greetings mean more when they acknowledge and celebrate our religious differences.. It was the day before Thanksgiving, and I was at my local coffee shop in New Haven, Conn. I had just finished ordering my preferred espresso drink, and as I paid for it the barista said to me, with good cheer, "Happy Thanksgiving, if you celebrate it." I was genuinely nonplused, and so, without considering how rude it might sound, I blurted back, "Who doesn't celebrate Thanksgiving?"

title: Canada's Resilience Allows Central Bank to Chart Its Own Course: Official
summary: Data support central bank's view that a slowdown in third-quarter growth was temporary, Deputy Gov. Timothy Lane says. OTTAWA-The Canadian economy's resilience has allowed the Bank of Canada to chart its own course by keeping interest rates steady while others have eased policy, a senior official said Thursday.

title: How Amazon Dodges Responsibility for Unsafe Products: The Case of the Hoverboard
summary: Resume Subscription. On Jan. 9, 2016, Nashville teen Matthew Fox was upstairs playing videogames while his parents, Brian and Megan Fox, were out getting supplies for his birthday party.

title: For Many Soldiers, Mental-Health Issues Start Before Enlistment
summary: Childhood trauma can be amplified by military service, studies show; emphasis on providing consistent mental-health care. Combat experience is often blamed as the root cause of suicidal behavior among veterans. But ongoing Army studies show that many troops with mental-health problems can trace them back to trauma experienced before they joined the military.

title: There's a Hole in My Life: The Golden State Warriors Are Gone.
summary: The NBA is shedding TV viewers. Is the decline of a great team at least partly to blame?. Television ratings for the NBA are down, not insignificantly, and because this is 2019, and everyone is an expert in absolutely everything, theories abound -some plausible, others less so.

title: Alberto-Culver Heir Navigates a Thorny Family Business Succession
summary: Carol Lavin Bernick describes the trials and tribulations of taking over a family business. Carol Lavin Bernick knows first hand the challenges and opportunities of working with family.

title: Why the Old Look Down on the Young
summary: The younger generation isn't getting worse; older people just like to think they are, according to a new study.. Ever since the Greeks, people have been complaining that the next generation is a disappointment. Nowadays, it's Boomers fighting with those aggravating, avocado-toast crunching, emoji-texting millennials. The feeling is seductive-but isn't it really an illusion? After all, the old folks who are complaining were once on the receiving end of the same complaints themselves. In the 1960s, the Boomers' parents denounced them as irresponsible hippies. Have people really been steadily deteriorating since ancient times?

title: Saudi-Russia Committee Recommends Deeper Oil Cuts
summary: Group within OPEC-plus wants the alliance to reduce production by a further 500,000 barrels a day. VIENNA-An oil producers' committee led by Saudi Arabia and Russia recommended deepening crude-production cuts by 42% next year, according to Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak, signaling the plan is likely to be adopted Thursday by OPEC.

title: New Shopping Habits May Help Gucci's Owner
summary: Reports that Kering has held deal talks with Moncler would be a major change of strategy for the luxury group. If Louis Vuitton is about to pair up with Tiffany, what should Gucci do? A big acquisition by the Italian brand's owner could be a helpful shift in strategy.

title: Electric Lights for Yuletide
summary: In 1882, Thomas Edison's business partner put up a Christmas tree decorated with 80 red, white and blue bulbs-and launched an American tradition.. As a quotation often attributed to Maya Angelou has it, ''You can tell a lot about a person by the way (s)he handles these three things: a rainy day, lost luggage and tangled Christmas tree lights." I'm not sure what it says about me that I actually look forward to getting my hands on the latter. My house is so brightly decorated with energy-saving LEDs that it could double as a landing beacon on a foggy night. It's the one thing I really missed when I lived abroad-no other country does Christmas lights like America. More than 80 million households put up lighting displays each December, creating a seasonal spike in U.S. energy use that's bigger than the annual consumption of some small countries.

title: So Your Dog Can Roll Over. Can It Pass a Co-op Board Interview?
summary: Blowouts and bowties, Xanax and Zoloft. New York's co-op buyers and their dogs are jumping through all sorts of hoops to get precious approval.. When retired couple Heidi DeCoo and Carl Norton decided to buy a small co-op apartment in Manhattan's Lenox Hill neighborhood as a city getaway from their home in Ithaca, N.Y., they encountered a strange request. The building's co-op board asked that they bring their two gray-haired schnoodles (a cross between a miniature schnauzer and a poodle) in for their interview.

title: Michaels Shares Slip Following Lower Guidance, Disappointing Quarter
summary: Craft retailer also recorded more than $30 million in impairment charges for its Darice wholesale business. Shares of Michaels Cos. fell after the company reported a drop in comparable-store sales in the third quarter and lowered its guidance for sales and adjusted earnings for the fiscal year.

title: Low Interest Rates Leave Retired Investors With Tough Choices
summary: Retirement columnist Glenn Ruffenach also offers advice about naming co-executors of an estate. I keep hearing that I need to invest more aggressively in retirement to ensure my savings last as long as I do. I have done quite well in the past 30 years or so with a fairly conservative/traditional mix of investments-about 60% in stocks and 40% in bonds. Here's my question: Does "conservative" still work in retirement? I worry about putting more money in stocks and then getting hit with a repeat of 2007-09 in the markets.

title: A NATO Summit With Multiple Disrupters
summary: At summit, President Trump found himself quickly drawn into conflict, though it was not all of his own design. This item first appeared in the Capital Journal newsletter. Read today's full newsletter here or sign up here for daily updates in your inbox.

title: Canada Trade Deficit Improved in October on U.S. Strength
summary: Trade surplus with U.S. hits decade-plus high; export decline to China weighed on results. OTTAWA-Canada's trade deficit of goods narrowed in October and came in slightly ahead of expectations, as exports advanced for only the second time in five months and the country's trade surplus with the U.S. hit a decade-plus high.

title: On Irish Isle Inis Meáin, Local Tradition Is Kept Alive
summary: A family-run restaurant, hotel and knitwear company are luring travelers who seek an understated approach to hospitality to one of Ireland's Aran Islands. We want pilgrims to come here, not tourists," says Tarlach de Blácam, co-owner of the Inis Meáin Knitting Company, a knitwear operation that sends its garments to boutiques and high-end department stores around the world. The 72-year-old Irishman is among the 160 year-round residents of Inis Meáin (or Inishmaan, as it's known in English), the middle isle of the three Aran Islands off the west coast of Ireland. Born in Dublin, de Blácam moved here in 1973 with his wife, Áine, who grew up on the island. The couple wanted their children to be fluent in the local Irish, which they consider an especially pure variant of the language.

summary: Trade group spent millions on lobbying but then filed suit Wednesday. The hospital industry is again turning to courts to do what its lobbyists couldn't: stop the latest health-care cost action from the White House.

summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Thursday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Thursday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Meet Wall Street's Rent Collector
summary: Redwood Trust sells $376 million bond backed by rent payments, its first deal since buying CoreVest American Finance in October. One of Wall Street's biggest bundlers of mortgage bonds has moved into rentals.

title: Marvelous Mrs. Maisel Bus Tour Pulls In to New York
summary: Resume Subscription. The Amazon series "The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel" has already proved itself a sensation with critics and viewers. The set-in-New York City show, which chronicles the rise of a female stand-up comic during the '50s, has also garnered a bevy of honors in its two seasons, including more than a dozen Emmy Awards.

title: Workplace Immigration Inquiries Quadruple Under Trump
summary: ICE unit's investigators open fewer cases related to gangs, weapons and financial crimes. WASHINGTON-Investigators with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement opened about four times the number of workplace investigations in the year ended Sept. 30 compared with the close of the Obama administration, while starting fewer probes into gangs, weapons and financial crimes, according to new figures the agency provided to The Wall Street Journal.

title: Dollar General Sales Climb in Latest Quarter
summary: Discount retailer's quarterly results beat estimates; shares jump. Dollar General Corp. reported robust customer demand in its latest quarter and exceeded Wall Street forecasts for sales and profit.

title: In Scotland, U.K. Election Shapes Up as Proxy Vote on Independence
summary: Resume Subscription. PERTH, Scotland-While the rest of the U.K. is arguing ahead of next week's elections about whether to leave the European Union, in this town on the silvery waters of the River Tay, another union is in question: Scotland's 300-year-old tie to England.

title: MetLife Expands Into Fast-Growing Sector: Pet Insurance
summary: Acquisition of PetFirst Healthcare fits with strategy to widen offerings, boost sales. MetLife Inc. said Thursday it purchased pet insurance company PetFirst Healthcare LLC, expanding into a growing industry as it aims to widen offerings and boost sales.

title: Lawmakers Expand List of Issues to Resolve as Spending Deadline Nears
summary: While border-wall funding remains the most divisive matter, gun violence and abortion are added to the mix. WASHINGTON-Border-wall funding has been the most divisive spending issue in Washington during the Trump administration, with Republicans pushing to increase funding for the project and Democrats resisting paying for it.

title: A Bumpy Road for Electric Vehicles in China
summary: Beijing wants even faster growth in EV sales than it did two years ago, but without subsidies. Beijing wants lots of electric vehicles, but no longer wants to pay for them. Car makers risk having to foot the bill instead.

title: Japan Approves $120 Billion Stimulus Package as Economic Clouds Gather
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's plan aims to counteract the effect of a recent sales-tax increase. TOKYO-Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's cabinet approved a $120 billion stimulus program, Japan's largest in more than three years, citing the same global economic risks that have led central banks in the U.S. and Europe to cut interest rates.

title: Shh! Companies Are Fixing Accounting Errors...Quietly
summary: Businesses are less likely to alert investors and reissue financial statements. Papa John's International Inc. this spring discovered an accounting error that had caused years of misstated financial numbers. The pizza chain decided the mistake wasn't serious enough to require it to reissue its financial statements.

title: Veteran President's Rift With Bolivian Military Helped Drive His Early Exit
summary: Evo Morales's background as a soldier initially enlisted the security services' support, but his leftist ideology and refusal to raise pay and pensions eroded loyalty as postelection protests mounted. LA PAZ, Bolivia-In a country where draft-dodging is endemic among the political elite, Evo Morales was Bolivia's only elected president to perform obligatory military service, drilling in 1978 with a mechanized cavalry brigade.

title: Taiwan Presidential Contender Cries Foul Over 'Pro-China' Label
summary: Opposition candidate Han Kuo-yu, who trails in opinion polls, says ruling party 'can't produce a good scorecard'. CHIAYI, Taiwan-Seeking a second term as Taiwan's leader, President Tsai Ing-wen has cast herself as a bulwark against authoritarian China's efforts to undermine democracy in the self-ruled island.

title: India's Central Bank Stands Pat Despite Pleas From Business, Policy Makers
summary: After five rate cuts this year, the RBI holds fire because of concerns about inflation. NEW DELHI-India's central bank left its lending rate unchanged, saying it was concerned about inflation, even as executives and policy makers have been demanding easing to help trigger the lending needed for Asia's third-largest economy to snap out of its growth slump.

title: Daily Mail's Online Reinvention Relieves Pressure Amid Newspaper-Industry Woes
summary: British paper's web edition, known for photo-heavy stories about vacationing celebrities and other tabloid fodder, has become one of the world's most-read news sites. The Daily Mail's transformation from a tabloid little known outside the U.K. to one of the world's most-read news websites is playing a key role in helping its parent company weather the downturn affecting newspapers world-wide.

title: American Companies Are Hungry for a Cut of China's Fake-Meat Market
summary: Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods face competition from local startups that aim to leverage their knowledge of Chinese tastes. Beyond Meat Inc. and Impossible Foods Inc. are considering China as their next big market for plant-based meat products, but local startups aim to leverage their own knowledge of Chinese tastes to gain an edge over the U.S. companies.

title: Taiwan's Isolation Will Diminish as China Reveals Its True Colors, Minister Says
summary: Island shows how democracies can resist mainland's sway, top diplomat says. TAIPEI-Taiwan's diplomatic isolation will diminish as foreign governments look to the island for a model of how democracies can stand up to Beijing, Foreign Minister Joseph Wu predicted, amid an international backlash against China's assertive foreign policy.

title: FTC Faces Push to Study Ads Targeting Children
summary: Pediatricians, consumer advocates urge agency to look into collecting children's data online. WASHINGTON-Pediatricians and consumer advocates are calling on the Federal Trade Commission to investigate practices for collecting online data about children, amid concerns advertisers might be manipulating children with targeted ads.

title: NYPD Digital Chief to Head City's Information-Technology Agency
summary: Jessica Tisch, a law-enforcement tech guru, aims to reboot the department that oversees NYC's digital efforts. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio has appointed a rising star in the field of law-enforcement technology to reboot the agency that oversees the city's internet services and telecommunications, officials said Wednesday.

title: What Is Insider Trading? House Passes Bill Setting a Clear Definition
summary: The legislation could make it more likely that recipients of improper tips will face prosecution, some lawyers say. WASHINGTON-The House moved to clear up uncertainty over the statutory definition of insider trading by passing a bill that explicitly defines-and bans-a crime that shakes investor confidence in the integrity of financial markets.

title: Sailor Kills Two People and Himself at Pearl Harbor Base
summary: Shooting in Hawaii takes place just days before anniversary of Japanese attack on base. An active-duty sailor killed two people and wounded another before killing himself on Wednesday at the Pearl Harbor shipyard in Hawaii, according to base officials.

title: He Rescued His Grandchildren From Syria. Then He Lost Them Again.
summary: Resume Subscription. GOTHENBURG, Sweden-Seven months ago, Patricio Galvez rescued his seven grandchildren from the rubble of Islamic State.

title: Ohio Finds Cases of Noncitizens Registered to Vote in 2018
summary: State's secretary of state says instances are 'exceedingly rare' thanks to controls and processes of election system. WASHINGTON-A small number of noncitizens allegedly voted in Ohio, the state's chief election official said, but he sought to assuage concerns about election integrity by noting that voter fraud is extremely rare.

title: U.S. Weighs Sending Additional Troops to the Middle East
summary: Officials are discussing deployment that includes dozens more ships and other military hardware to counter threat from Iran. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is considering a significant expansion of the U.S. military footprint in the Middle East to counter Iran, including dozens more ships, other military hardware and as many as 14,000 additional troops, U.S. officials said.

title: New Problems With Takata Air Bags Prompt Recall of 1.4 Million Cars
summary: The recall affects cars with certain air bags produced by Takata between 1995 and 1999. Auto makers will likely recall 1.4 million cars after new problems were discovered with air bags produced in the 1990s by Takata Corporation, opening another front in the already giant effort to make sure drivers are safe from some devices made by the company.

title: Alaska Taps New CIO After Long Search
summary: Ex-Army official Bill Smith takes over effort to consolidate statewide IT services. Alaska has named a permanent chief information officer, more than a year after the previous CIO left, to be followed by several interim technology leaders.

title: Biden Proposes $1 Trillion in New Corporate Taxes
summary: Democratic candidate would raise minimum rates on companies to pay for health-care, climate, infrastructure and education policies. Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden proposed nearly $1 trillion in new corporate taxes on Wednesday as he sought to generate more revenue to pay for his policy plans on health care, climate, infrastructure and education.

title: New Jersey Revamps Response to Police Use-of-Force Incidents
summary: State's attorney general issues new mandates, including early-intervention programs and prompt investigations. New Jersey is overhauling how police agencies across the state investigate officer misconduct, including use-of-force incidents.

title: Steven Cohen Nears Deal to Buy Majority Stake in New York Mets
summary: Current owner Fred Wilpon and operating chief Jeff Wilpon would stay in their positions for next five years. Billionaire Steven A. Cohen is close to an agreement to purchase a majority stake in the New York Mets from Fred and Jeff Wilpon, a move that would give the hedge-fund manager control over a prominent baseball franchise that has disappointed fans and struggled with financial pressures in recent years.

title: A Modest Proposal for America's Teens
summary: A national exchange program could reduce partisan prejudice.. After the 2016 election, students from two high schools-one in Chicago and the other in rural Wisconsin-took turns visiting each other. The field trips were designed to help students understand each other's politics and ways of life.

title: Schiff's Surveillance State
summary: The Democrat demands, and then discloses, the call logs of his opponents.. Democrats are trying to convince Americans that President Trump should be ousted for trying to "dig up dirt" on a rival. They'd have more credibility if they didn't abuse their surveillance powers for drive-by smears of Republicans and a free press.

title: A Holiday Micro-Aggression
summary: Nowadays a spin-bike ad is sexist exploitation.. It used to be a corny joke if a dim-witted man bought his wife a vacuum cleaner for Christmas. In our woke era, any gift can now be interpreted as a sexist micro-aggression. Witness the cultural panic over a Peloton ad for high-tech exercise bikes.

title: Food Stamps in Good Times
summary: The jobless rate is 3.6%. When better to renew work requirements?. Judging by the rhetoric, you'd think President Trump was shutting down Great Depression bread lines. "The Trump administration," Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said, "is driving the vulnerable into hunger just as the Christmas season approaches."

title: 'The Ship of Dreams' Review: A Doomed Civilization
summary: Tectonic pressures were building, socially and politically, well before an iceberg loomed in the North Atlantic and tore into the Titanic's hull.. Even in an age when human disasters are all too common, the story of the Titanic, the unsinkable ship, has the power to haunt us. Today it is a cliché that stability is mostly an illusion, that danger lurks amid seeming security-isn't that the lesson of so many financial meltdowns, not to mention terrorist attacks?

title: The Democrats' Fractured Fairy Tales
summary: Kamala Harris and Nancy Pelosi should have a talk about the destructive siren song of their party's leftwing ideology.. Kamala Harris and Nancy Pelosi should have a talk. Both answered the siren song of the modern Democratic left. On Tuesday, Sen. Harris's campaign broke up on the rocks. Meanwhile Speaker Pelosi, who stuffed her ears this summer against the left's calls to impeach President Trump, sails on toward impeachment. That won't end well either.

title: 'The Interagency' Isn't Supposed to Rule
summary: The Constitution gives the president, not a club of unelected officials, the power to set foreign policy.. Enthusiasm over entrepreneurship is now found in every corner of society-even, apparently, within the federal bureaucracy. Witness after witness in last month's House impeachment inquiry hearings referred to "the interagency," an off-the-books informal government organization that we now know has enormous power to set and execute American foreign policy.

title: Get Ready for a Contested Convention
summary: Superdelegates may end up deciding the Democrats' 2020 presidential nominee.. There's growing concern among Democrats that their July 2020 convention in Milwaukee could open without a candidate who receives a majority of the vote on the first ballot. The last time that happened to the Democrats was 1952.

title: The T-Shirt Primary
summary: Your 'That Little Girl Was Me' outfit has suddenly become a collector's item.. Modern politicians need to be skilled in the use of three tools: social media, cable television and T-shirts. While social media generates buzz and cable TV drives the conversation, T-shirts are becoming a favorite way to deliver a message on the campaign trail.

title: Warren's Insight on Teacher Pay
summary: Spending rises, but layers of bureaucracy swallow up taxpayer money before it can reach the classroom.. When education-reform activist Sarah Carpenter expressed skepticism about Sen. Elizabeth Warren's plan to quadruple federal Title I funding for schools, Ms. Warren's reply was remarkable.

summary: 'I have noticed a grave oversight. While erudite and experienced, none of the witnesses are persons of color.'. Rep. Al Green (D., Texas) speaking on the House floor Dec. 4:

title: Democrats Signal Impeachment May Go Beyond Ukraine
summary: Judiciary Committee hearing includes questions about breadth of alleged wrongdoing. WASHINGTON-Democrats signaled their impeachment case centered on President Trump's dealings with Ukraine could include multiple alleged offenses, including bribery, abuse of power and obstruction of both Congress and justice, at a hearing that marked the start of the next phase in the impeachment inquiry.

title: Newsom Slams PG&E Insurance Deal as Wildfire Settlement Takes Shape
summary: California governor criticizes $11 billion pact that locks up votes for company's bankruptcy plan. PG&E Corp. is nearing a settlement with victims of the wildfires that pushed the utility into bankruptcy, while clashing with California Gov. Gavin Newsom about the best path out of chapter 11.

title: The U.S. Furniture Industry Is Back-but There Aren't Enough Workers
summary: Resume Subscription. HICKORY, N.C-Here's the good news: There are now more reasons to make furniture in the U.S. than at any point since the financial crisis. Crate & Barrel and Williams-Sonoma Inc. are expanding manufacturing in the U.S., and the factories of longtime furniture makers are humming.

title: Regulators See Nonbank Mortgage Firms as Potential Risk to U.S. Financial System
summary: The lenders, which aren't regulated as closely as banks, originate and service a growing portion of U.S. home loans. WASHINGTON-Financial regulators identified fast-growing mortgage lending companies as a potential source of instability in the U.S. financial system, while finding that overall risks are moderate.
